moves.2. c3: The Alapin. Avoids many book lines.
moves.2... Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. cxd4 e6 5. d5 exd: A very advanced pawn! No real development on either side.
moves.8. Nc3 Qe5+ 9. Be2 Ng6 10. Nb5: Knight is now threatening Nc7+ winning the rook.
moves.11... Qe6 12. Ng5: Attacking the queen and threatening Nxf7 (which will win the rook).
moves.12... Qf6 13. Qd5:
Queen is now safe to advance this far.
Both Black bishops are trapped.
moves.14. Ne4: Threatening both the Queen and the h-knight.
moves.14... Qe6 15. Bc4: I prefer to exchange with a recapture.
moves.15... Ne5 16. Nc7: Forks rook and queen, guarding own queen.
moves.17... Bxd6 18. Nxa8: Exchanging a rook for a pawn.
moves.18... Re8 19. Nxd6: The pin is not scary. All options can be defused.
moves.19... Rf8: With a strong lead it's now just a matter of exchanging off.
moves.20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. O-O-O: Covers the bishop (and later the rook).
moves.21... b6: Trying to finally get some life out of the trapped bishop.
moves.22... Bxb7 23. Nxb7+ Kc8: Here I can't keep both knights.
moves.24. Nd6+ Kb8 25. Nxb6: The best that I can do with the knight is to break up the last of the paired pawns.
moves.25... axb6 26. Rhe1: The knight on d6 prevents the Re8/Nd3 trap which would win a rook.
moves.26... Nc6: The plan is now to force the exchange.
moves.27. Re8+ Rxe8 28. Nxe8 Kc8 29. Nd6+: A pawn won on the next move.  Black conceded that there was not much left.
